awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation in Life STEM Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the core values of the National Science Foundation is ensuring inclusiveness among all segments of the broader scientific community. This Life STEM project will provide a mechanism for strengthening minority serving institutions' capacity to help the nation meet the growing demand for a more diverse future STEM workforce. The workshop will provide opportunities for these institutions to increase their capacity to inspire, prepare, and retain underrepresented K-12 and undergraduate students in life science and bioscience fields through innovative models of interventions. To enhance the capacity of these institutions to participate in this endeavor, the workshop will focus on cutting edge research designs and review models of intervention shown to be effective in helping retain underrepresented students in the STEM pipeline.

Working in concert with the Quality Education for Minority Network and MER Associates, Spelman College will host a workshop for 100-125 key university administrators, education and STEM researchers, and sponsored research office representatives. The workshop attendees will participate in teams of 4-5 members to learn more about the Foundation's mission and goals for STEM education and for broadening participation in STEM. Teams will be provided support to attend the workshop where representatives can also share best practices about individual successes in helping underrepresented students complete courses of study in STEM fields.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the Broadening Participation in Life STEM Workshop was to increase the number of investigators at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) receiving funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF). The goal was to promote workshops and assist individuals from MSIs in developing and writing winning proposals, identifying the appropriate funding mechanisms, and help pursue and sustain funding. The workshop also served to highlight faculty current research endeavors and increase their publication efforts. Another objective of the project was to produce interdisciplinary relationships in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) areas.  

 

A workshop was held in December 2021 in collaboration with Understanding Interventions (UI). The goal of the workshop was to develop leaders in broadening participation and to help provide tools needed to highlight work being done at various institutional environments. The overall goal being to increase inequities in the STEM field. 

 

Some outcomes of this project were:  

 

  • A group of faculty interested in writing about STEM identity was formed. This was organized by the Center of Excellence for Minority Women at Spelman College. 
  • A writing group was formed by the department chairs in the Division of Natural Sciences and Mathematics at Spelman College. A book has been proposed to discuss showcase historical, empirical, and anecdotal efforts towards training Black women in STEM. 
  • Across all the workshops, there were a total of 127 participants. 48.3% were faculty, 27.6% administrators and 20.7% researchers. 
  • Over 120 manuscripts submitted for peer review. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/22/2022
Modified by: Viveka Borum
